docs.lead_paragraph: A chemical found in broccoli and broccoli sprouts shows promise as a potential treatment for Helicobacter pylori, the bacterium that causes ulcers and raises the risk of stomach cancer, according to a study being published today in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Researchers from Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore and the National Center for Scientific Research in Paris tested the chemical, sulforaphane, in mice and human cells under laboratory conditions.
docs.abstract: Researchers at Johns Hopkins University and National Center for Scientic Research in Paris, in report in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, find that sulforaphane, chemical found in broccoli and broccoli sprouts, shows promise as potential treatment for Helicobacter pylori, bacterium that causes ulcers and raises risk of stomach cancer; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The warm breeze embraced me as I left earth on that shining morning. I ran down a gentle hill, legs stretched forward, my arms extended out as wings. I soared in perfect flight. Lifted gracefully above a flowered hill, my body was strong, my vision flawless, and I could see forever.

headline.main: My Body, My Prison, My Dreams

docs.abstract: Richard M Cohen Cases essay describes his feelings as man diminished by multiple sclerosis and colon cancer (M)
docs.snippet: The warm breeze embraced me as I left earth on that shining morning. I ran down a gentle hill, legs stretched forward, my arms extended out as wings. I soared in perfect flight.    Lifted gracefully above a flowered hill, my body was strong, my...

docs.lead_paragraph: MaryBeth Zea of Little Falls, Minn., was only 28, married but childless, when breast cancer struck in 1988. The surgeon who performed her mastectomy told her that because her cancer was not hormone-sensitive, pregnancy would probably not make much difference to her chances of a recurrence. He told her that pregnancy was a personal choice. But MaryBeth was afraid that the stress of pregnancy and its outpouring of hormones could stimulate a regrowth of cancer. She also feared what would become of a baby if she should get sick again. And so she chose to remain childless and devote herself instead to her marriage and career, now as a still-healthy portrait photographer.

headline.main: Cancer and Childbirth: Mutually Exclusive No Longer

docs.abstract: Article on changes in cancer treatment aimed at preserving fertility while curing cancers; notes more than 75 percent of children with cancer are being cured, but little is known about side effects of treatment beyond first decade; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Understanding Depression,'' by Dr. J. Raymond DePaulo Jr. and Leslie Alan Horvitz, John Wiley & Sons, $24.95. There are three audiences for this authoritative book: people who think they may be depressed, those whose condition has already been diagnosed and are in treatment, and those who are concerned about someone who is either in treatment or probably needs to be.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Writing to Heal the Soul,'' by Susan Zimmerman, Three Rivers Press, $13. Can writing heal sorrow and pain? The answer, as the author of this inspiring little book sees it, is a resounding yes.
docs.abstract: John Langone reviews book Writing to Heal the Soul by Susan Zimmerman; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New findings that excite cancer researchers often ring hollow to cancer patients. The reason is that the two groups have different expectations. For researchers, an exciting development may mean that a drug undergoing early trials delays the progress of an advanced cancer for an extra month or two in 30 percent of a small group of dying patients. For patients, an exciting development means that the new drug will provide extra years of life.

headline.main: Expanding Horizons, and Expectations, in Cancer Care

docs.abstract: Article on different ways that cancer researchers, patients, doctors, politicians, federal agencies and charities view medical developments, new therapies and promising new drugs; few researchers were disappointed, but patients and others were, when no apparent apparent major breakthroughs in lung, breast, prostate or colorectal cancer were reported at recent annual meeting of American Society of Clinical Oncology in Orlando, Fla; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A change is as good as a rest for a brain worn down by working too long on one task, according to a study released yesterday in the journal Nature Neuroscience. A group of researchers tried to find out why too much practice could make performance slump.
docs.abstract: Study led by Harvard psychologist Dr Sara Mednick, published in journal Nature Neuroscience, finds that one-hour nap in early afternoon provides power boost for people working for long time on one task (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Combining a ''supercleaning'' technique developed for lead abatement with periodic pest control can sharply reduce the cockroach allergens that have been linked to high rates of asthma in urban areas, according to a new study. The study, presented last week at a conference of the American Thoracic Society in Atlanta, suggests that the combination can be a cost-effective approach for preventing some asthma cases.
docs.abstract: Temple University researcher Dr Steven Kelsen, presenting study at American Thoracic Society conference in Atlanta, says combining 'supercleaning' technique developed for lead abatement with periodic pest control can sharply reduce cockroach allergens linked to high rates of asthma in urban areas; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An Italian woman who was allergic to her husband's kisses was the subject of a recent case study in The Lancet. There was nothing wrong with the woman's marriage, and the allergic reaction that she suffered was a literal one, to an antibiotic that her husband was taking.

headline.main: It's in His Kiss? This Time, Yes

docs.abstract: Group of doctors in Naples, Italy, in case study published in Lancet, finds that woman suffering from itching and swelling after kissing her husband was allergic to antibiotic her husband had been taking; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: An Italian woman who was allergic to her husband's kisses was the subject of a recent case study in The Lancet.    There was nothing wrong with the woman's marriage, and the allergic reaction that she suffered was a literal one, to an antibiotic that...

docs.lead_paragraph: I slowed down as I approached a fork in the highway, unsure of which arm to take. The driver behind me was on my tail, so impatient that he tried to pass me on the right just as I headed for the right fork, forcing him to slam on his brakes. He became so infuriated that he pulled right in front of my car and each time I moved he repeatedly slammed on his brakes, forcing me to brake suddenly again and again, endangering not only me but himself and the driver behind me.

headline.main: Why Angry People Can't Control the Short Fuse

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on hostility and anger and link to early heart attacks and stroke; describes how to recognize hostility, what triggers anger and how to calm down; drawing (M)
